awd_titl_txt: Precision Studies of Neutrino Oscillations and Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was recently confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the Higgs mass has the value it has and why there is no antimatter in the universe. A primary area to search for answers to these and other open questions about the universe, how it came to be and why it is the way it is, is to focus on a study of the properties of neutrinos and to use what we know and can learn about neutrinos as probes of science beyond the Standard Model. Neutrinos are those elementary particles that interact with practically nothing else in the universe. They have no electric charge and were once thought to be massless. Like other elementary particles, they were believed to have an antimatter counterpart, the antineutrino. Moreover, the Standard Model predicted that there were actually three different kinds of neutrinos that were distinguishable through the different interactions that they did undergo whenever there was an interaction. But recent measurements have totally changed our picture of neutrinos. We now know that neutrinos do have a mass and because they do, they can actually change from one type to another. Detailed measurements of these changes, along with other current neutrino experiments, form one of the most promising ways to probe for new physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM), and are the subject of this investigation. This research will involve the work of two post-doctoral researchers as well as graduate and undergraduate students.

This award supports work, using the neutrino beam at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL), on three related neutrino experiments: MINERvA, Nova and MINOS+ all measuring neutrino oscillations: muon neutrino to electron neutrino transitions. To correctly measure these transitions, precise knowledge of neutrino interactions is required. This award will be used to measure (using the MINERvA detector) these interactions across a wide energy range available at FNAL. This will improve our knowledge of the neutrino flux, useful for future Short Baseline (detector near the source at FNAL) and Long Baseline (detector hundreds of kilometers away) experiments as well as the current Nova experiment. The work on the MINOS+ experiment will help map out the shape of the energy dependence of the neutrino oscillation probability, which could reveal new anomalies in the neutrino sector. A number of BSM proposed phenomena, from sterile neutrinos to extra dimensions, can cause measurable deviations in the neutrino oscillation probability in the 4-10GeV range.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project allowed our group to continue studies of the chargeless, but slightly massive, particles called neutrinos. Neutrinos interact very weakly and matter (such as the Earth itself!) is almost entirely transparent for them. We observe neutrinos using a powerful neutrino beam and large (multi kiloton, kt) detectors separated by hundreds of miles. Neutrinos come in three types (called electron, muon, and tau) and have the ability to transform from one type to another as they travel over long distances. This process is called oscillations. By observing oscillations we can measure six of the twenty six parameters in the fundamental theory of physics known as the Standard Model. 

 

Our group has a leadership role in NOvA, an experiment that measures muon neutrino oscillations to tau and electron neutrinos. The neutrinos are produced by the NuMI neutrino beam at Fermilab, a national lab located in the Chicago suburbs. NOvA has two detectors, a 300 ton "near detector" at Fermilab and a 14 kt "far detector" located 810 km away in Minnesota. During the project period NOvA published an analysis of muon neutrino oscillations. The results are shown in three figures attached to this report. The figures demonstrate oscillations between muon and electron neutrinos. The data allow NOvA to measure three of the six parameters mentioned above. The most important parameter is "delta". If delta is not 0, pi, or 2pi that could explain why our universe has an excess of matter over antimatter, in part answering the question "How are we here?" The NOvA Parameter Measurements figure shows NOvA's measurement of delta and another parameter, theta23. Colored regions are allowed by the data and white are excluded. This is the major NOvA result from the award period. The analysis was done by our group's postdoc and graduate students led by our PIs. 

 

Our group has a number of important roles in the MINERvA neutrino-nucleus scattering experiment. Since neutrinos only interact weakly, we must infer their type and energy based on the results of their interactions. For precision oscillation experiments our knowledge of neutrino interactions must be correspondingly precise. MINERvA measures the rate of neutrino interactions. In each interaction MINERvA can also measure the identity and energy of each outgoing particle, allowing it to infer the neutrino energy. The neutrino interaction rate is the product of the number of neutrinos passing through the detector (called the flux) and the probability that any one of them will interact (called the cross-section). MINERvA wants to infer cross-sections from the measured rates. This requires knowledge of the flux. 

 

A graduate student and PI in our group were responsible for the flux prediction, shown an attached figure. The prediction was made by combining a simulation of the beam with external data that shows how protons and other hadrons (particles that interact via the strong nuclear force) interact and produce secondary hadrons that eventually decay to produce neutrinos.  The flux prediction is the most precise of its kind. One of our group's postdocs was also responsible for a measurement of the flux using the rate of neutrinos scattering off of atomic electrons. That process has a well known cross-section so we can infer the flux from the rate.

 

Knowledge of the flux allows MINERvA to measure cross-sections. Two graduate students and PI in our group were responsible for measurements of the cross-section for muon neutrinos to interact and produce a muon along with a number of hadrons. The cross-section was measured for interactions on plastic targets as a function of neutrino energy. The result is shown in an attached figure. Another graduate student was responsible for measurements of the muon neutrino cross-section on different targets and as a function of other kinematic variables.

 

Our group was also active in the forthecoming DUNE neutrino oscillation experiment. We constructed a prototype of the high voltage field cage and operated it in a liquid argon cryostat at Fermilab. Our group's postdoc was responsible for a camera system that could operate in liquified argon (at −302.5 F) and was used in the ProtoDUNE-SP detector at CERN. We have a leadership role in the R&D and conceptual design of the near detector.

Broader impacts

Our project impacted society beyond high energy physics in several ways. The project funded summer stipends for undergraduates that allow them to participate in HEP experiments and develop their research skills. The project also provided professional training for undergraduate and graduate students in computing, big data analysis, scientific instrument development, experimental operation, and communication of technical information. Six graduate students obtained the PhD and transitioned to industrial or national laboratory jobs during the project period. The project also provided funds and supplies to operate an after-school STEM program at a local elementary school. The school's annual Rocket Day is shown in an attached figure.
